data.text:
If you were Evangelical in the 1980s and 1990s, you knew about Elisabeth Elliot. She was the religionâ€™s central teacher on sex. What were her qualifications?

She was the widow of Jim Elliot, of course. He was the missionary killed in Ecuador in 1956. Sheâ€™d written his story in Through Gates of Splendor (1957), and a biography, Shadow of the Almighty (1958), each received as â€œclassics,â€ as he became known as a â€œmartyr.â€

So that made her pretty close to God.

She was anti-feminist, anti-gay, pro-female â€˜submissionâ€™. But the great war of Elisabeth Elliotâ€™s life was against premarital sex, which she called â€˜impureâ€™. She made the case in a 1984 book, Passion and Purity, which for many Evangelicals was Godâ€™s guide for dating and marriage.

She told the story of her courtship with Jim.

In 1948, they were at Wheaton College, a Christian school in Illinois. She describes him as â€œa real man, strong, broadchested, unaffected, friendly, and I thought, very handsome.â€

The action began when Jim was a junior, she a senior about to graduate. They took a walk together, and out it came.

â€œCome on, Bett. Donâ€™t tell me you didnâ€™t know I was in love with you?â€

â€œI had no idea.â€

There followed five years of occasional meetings and letters, all marked by the great Elliot themes: suffering as ennobling, waiting on divine guidance, and not having sex.

She sold a dream of controlled eroticism.

She writes in the book: â€œIt is possible to love passionately and to stay out of bed. I know. We did it.â€

Even before Elisabeth Elliot died in 2015, some were thinking the courtship story was looking a little funny. Dr. Kimberly B. George, the Christian feminist scholar, writes in 2010:

â€œWhen I re-read Passion and Purity I was actually appalled at how her boyfriend/husband Jim had treated her. Here was a relationship I had idealized in my teenage years, and yet when I read the story now (especially having a psychology background), I am deeply disturbed at all the ways he led her on, criticized her, refused to commit to her, and yet spiritualized all his actions. The story somehow seemed so romantic when I was sixteen; now it seems to verge on emotional abuse and manipulation.â€

You had to take Elisabeth Elliotâ€™s word for most of it.

In 1978, she published Jimâ€™s journalsâ€” or some of them. The archives page at Wheaton College notes: â€œIn several places in Elliotâ€™s journals, comments have been cut out.â€

I visited in person. They werenâ€™t kidding.

After her mother died, the Elliotsâ€™ one child, Valerie Elliot Shepard, rounded up their love letters.

A few had been quoted in Elisabeth Elliot books, especially in Passion and Purity. Most hadnâ€™t. In 2019, Shephard publishes about half of them as Devotedly: The Personal Letters and Love Story of Jim and Elisabeth Elliot.

Snippets of Bettyâ€™s journal were also published, with lots (and lots) of editorializing by Shepard, trying to keep the story on track. But collating the accounts, I started to wonder what the hell was going on.

Early on, Betty sees herself as â€œwholly set apart.â€ She attends a wedding, weeping for joy because sheâ€™d been given some private message from God sheâ€™d not marryâ€”so â€œwinning victory in that realm.â€

But Betty had some kind of inner â€˜struggleâ€™, left unstated. â€œI cannot write it even here,â€ she writes. â€œO God, purge me, take away all desire!â€

The prospect of a romance with Jim was unsettling.

She writes in her diary: â€œEach of us has built up a sort of code, his on Matt. 19:12, mine on 1 Cor. 7 and Is. 54. Now what about these? Have we failed? Have we lost our vision?â€

Jim was citing Jesusâ€™ teaching to be a â€œeunuch for the kingdom.â€ Her â€œcodeâ€ from Isaiah 54 wouldâ€™ve been: â€œSing, barren woman.â€

But then Jim asks her to go on a walk and says he loves her. Their dialogue in parting seems less than lovestruck. As Betty records the scene, Jim is oddly muttering, â€œIt is going to be hard . . . harder than weâ€™d like to think.â€

Not hearing from Jim, she writes that she â€œmissesâ€ him.

He starts writing her, and she arranges to visit him again. We see Jim in his journal trying to talk himself into being â€œnatural.â€ He writes:

â€œI am learning, I think, what Billy talks of, the giving out of natural love â€” it wastes easily with possession. If ever I am to love her, it must be Godâ€™s love in me â€” my own will not last, I know. I fear that the excitement of her presence roused me to an aggressiveness in my ardor that I do not really feel.â€

Iâ€™m struck by the regular references to â€˜Billyâ€™, â€˜Bill. C.â€™, i.e. Bill Cathers, a friend lurking around the edges of Elliot lore. With the letters in Devotedly, we can now see Elisabeth Elliot trimming Bill out of the narrative of Passion and Purity. Jimâ€™s letter to her of October 1, 1948 is quoted saying this:

â€œWhat makes me tremble is that I might allow something else (Betty Howard, for instance) to take the place that my God should have. Now something tells me that I can maybe have them both.â€

As Devotedly reveals, the actual second sentence was: â€œNow something tells me that I can maybe have them both, as both you and Billy have ministered to me lately.â€

Even Jimâ€™s letter as presented was strange.

He thinks of sex, he tells Betty, as a â€˜monsterâ€™. He continues:

â€œI cannot for the life of me understand my heart. Somewhere down deep in the murky pools of consciousness, there is a great monster whom I will name â€˜Wantâ€™ for just now. This is the only constant thing about me â€” Desire.â€

Jim goes on to say he and Betty must not touch anymore.

â€œI must confess to you, Betty, that I have had regrets about going even as far as we did in our physical contact, and that was very little as most judge.â€

Jim quotes Nietzscheâ€™s Thus Spake Zarathustra to her: â€œFor too long hath there been a slave and a tyrant concealed in woman. On that account woman is not capable of friendship: she knoweth only love.â€

The solution to the problem of a womanâ€™s love, Jim says, is Billyâ€™s example.

To have a man write his sort-of girlfriend telling her to act like his best friend, on the advice of Nietzsche . . . was a little weird?

Jim loved that â€˜David and Jonathanâ€™ thing.

Over and over in his journal, he sees himself as Jonathan, the biblical prince of 2 Samuel who, out of love for a divine young man, gives up his own kingship. This is the love that â€œpasses the love of women.â€

He writes in his journal:

â€œThe love of David and Jonathan (1:23â€“26) â€” felt again today for Bill C. upon receipt of a letter from him en route to China. How great shall be our fellowship in heaven! Oh, to spend eternity with such whose spirit quickens my own â€” makes me throb just to hear his soulâ€™s surgings.â€

When Bill got a girlfriend and was fading out of his life, Jim prays for a replacement: â€œLord, give me a David, I pray â€” one whom I can know as David knew Jonathan â€” â€˜sweet, swifter, strongerâ€¦â€™â€

But commenting on Betty, Jim seems self-lacerating, even panicked.

He writes in his journals, January 17, 1949. â€œO God, how can she desire me? Have I played the part so well that she actually thinks me worthy of womanâ€™s love? I tremble, Lord, at what surprises she shall know when all secret thoughts of men shall be manifest.â€

He returns to longing for a male companion, as in his entry on July 23, 1949: â€œRestless to do other things more directly related to the Lordâ€™s work. Longing for a companion, who will be a David to me, and me his Jonathan.â€

He has low periods.

He writes: â€œHeavy and sorrowful because of my coldness, insincerity, and fruitlessness. Oh, how needy â€” what emptiness I feel. I am not ready to see the King in his beauty.â€

The next day: â€œMy love is faint; my warmth practically nil . . . I donâ€™t love; I donâ€™t feel; I donâ€™t understand; I can only believe.â€

Then Jimâ€™s took to traveling with Peter Fleming. Intending to become an English professor, Pete was doing a thesis on Melvilleâ€™s overtly homoerotic novel, The Confidence Man.

As Olive, his future wife, reconstructs Peteâ€™s dialogue of the time: â€œHow can I spend my career talking about material that dwells so much on the base part of life? It is so contrary to Christian truth.â€

Then Pete thought he might become a Bible scholar. But under Jimâ€™s influence, they decided to be missionaries â€” together â€” in Ecuador.

Jimâ€™s correspondence with Elisabeth is often cold, agonized, and sometimes hostile.

Jim writes: â€œIf Betty Howard is a block of ice, Jim Elliot is a hunk of marble.â€ He calls them â€œbrother and sisterâ€ as he returns to talk of an â€œaching void.â€

He notes, over and over, his duty not to marry. â€œI feel quite confident that God wants me to begin jungle work, single,â€ he writes her.

She visits his parentsâ€™ home. Itâ€™s an utter disaster. His parents hated her, Jim reports in a letter, with details on why they hate her. His mother, he reports, â€œthinks you uncommunicative, possessed of a â€˜meek and quiet spirit,â€™ but a very poor maker of friends, and hence a poor prospective missionary.â€

He quotes his father sizing her up: â€œno face, no form, a spindly dreamer who has cleverly set her cap on you, and you have bitten.â€

Jim agrees with them? â€œI donâ€™t write now as if they were all wrong and that you must be excused from all these charges.â€

Betty replies: â€œI could hardly believe what I read, and I was utterly crushed by it.â€

They debate whether to continue writing. He says: â€œMy answer from the Lord about marriage is now a decided â€˜noâ€™ so long as present conditions prevail.â€

Betty wants to get married, and doesnâ€™t?

Sheâ€™ll wait for whenever God gives him permission, she says. Someday in the future, theyâ€™d maybe be together?

In the meantime, she fumes: â€œYou and Pete must be having the time of your young lives. My, what a contrast your situation is to mine!â€

She has her own doubts about the relationship, writing in her journal: â€œMy conscience (I guess it is my conscience) condemns me constantly.â€

They meet occasionally. From his journal: â€œAnd then I cried, and we walked. I couldnâ€™t understand why I was unable to explain sensibly just why it was not time for engagement.â€

Jim writes love letters . . . to Jesus.

â€œ . . . if only I may see Him, smell His garments, and smile into my Loverâ€™s eyes, ah, then, not stars, nor children, shall matter â€” only Himself.â€

And he writes Betty too.

The biblical references and God-talk are so heavy that itâ€™s never clear what anyone is really feeling or experiencing.

But many passages suggest unclear psychosexual profiles. When Betty gets to Ecuador, sheâ€™s troubled by male behaviors. She bemoans: â€œMen here do not know the meaning of the â€˜cold shoulder,â€™ and ogle and whoop at me.â€

She sees unclothed men bathing in a river, washing clothes. She writes:

â€œMy whole being recoils at such sights â€” not that I am shocked, in the sense of â€˜surprisedâ€™ or horrified, but it is a shock to my nature. I cannot express just how it affects me.â€

It makes her long for the Second Coming.

Betty joins the missionaries, as Jim vacillates.

He writes in his journal: â€œSpoke of engagement. She thinks Iâ€™m inconsistent, Lord, seeming to be self-contradictory so often in speaking plainly of marriage and then seeming to be so unsure about it all. â€

On July 11, 1952, he writes a prayer: â€œGive me not to be hungering for the â€˜strange, rare, and peculiarâ€™ when the common, ordinary, and regular, rightly taken, will suffice to feed and satisfy the soul.â€

The phrase â€œstrange, rare, and peculiarâ€ is from homeopathy, and refers to symptoms of illness which elude explanation. In The Principles and Art of Cure by Homoeopathy (1936), the phrase points to â€œabnormalities of the sexual functions.â€

Jim has passages of affection for Betty. They tend to oddly feminize him. He writes in his journal on July 30, 1952:

â€œI donâ€™t understand what there is about loving her that makes me such a damned woman. I can hardly begin to describe it; I only know that I feel it strong and that I canâ€™t talk of it without twists coming to my mouth. Lips get dry and tears seem to brim at my eyes, and there is a crushing sense in my chest.â€

In October 1953, they marry!

In Elisabeth Elliotâ€™s tellings this was the happy result engineered by God, who finally gave them the â€œgreen light.â€ But the new official biography, Becoming Elisabeth Elliot, by Ellen Vaughn, notes the marriage happened mostly because a job came available for a married couple.

â€œHow soon can you marry me?â€ Jim asked Betty.

In Jimâ€™s long-suppressed final journal entry, which I found in the Wheaton archive, he goes to his death talking of regretting the marriage, with hints of a divorce in the works.

And then he died.

Then, through Elisabeth Elliotâ€™s books, a character named â€œJim Elliotâ€ became the great Evangelical devoted husband-loverâ€”tender, godly, insisting on correct morals.

She could get prickly when mentioning Jimâ€™s early talk of â€˜woman-hatingâ€™. In a 1983 speech, when talking to a crowd of college students, she says:

â€œIt had nothing to do with being Jimâ€™s â€˜thing.â€™ It had nothing to do with his temperament or preferences. He really did like women.â€

Elliot fans werenâ€™t ones to scrutinize details.

Starry-eyed effusions over the great love of Jim and Betty continue to this day. The Evangelical blogger Ann Swindell writes:

â€œTheir story of Godâ€™s provision and their commitment to purity is truly incredible; their love is the stuff of fairy tales.â€

I ask Kimberly George how sheâ€™d wrap it up. She replies:

â€œI remain convinced EE wrote a story for the public based on very little actual truth of their relationship. I think she was likely miserable in their dynamics, but she loved to write â€” her writing meant a great deal to her. I think he was emotionally abusive. And yes, not so sure either was â€˜straightâ€™ in any conventional wayâ€¦but were trying to fit into a toxic script that they then reproduced in mass through Christian media.â€

And thatâ€™s the love story of Jim and Betty Elliot. ğŸ”¶
